 Hell must have frozen over. I actually agree with you - I think.
 Good for NGLTF. I think the gay politicos have sucked up to the Democrats while getting nothing in return except, as you say (gasp), "token support." The gay support of Clinton was shameful. He botched and then worsened the gays in the military and then actually signed DOMA. There are no politicians who have the guts to stand up to the religious right - directly and honestly - and say there is nothing wrong with being gay, cut it out. The dems maintain this wishy-washy relationship, trying to please all, but they will sell us out in a heartbeat - and do.

 It's about time that the democratic party stopped being just half a degree better than the republicans in their gay stances, and started actually being FOR equality.

 Are the democrats only going to get something done about gay rights when the republicans finally start having majority support for it?

foundit66

http://www.365gay.com/Newscon06/05/051106deanUp.htm
 
 Thursday morning Dean was busy trying to mend fences with the gay community.
 
 "I misstated the Democratic Party's platform, which does not say that marriage should be limited to a man and a woman, but says the Party is committed to full inclusion of gay and lesbian families in the life of our nation and leaves the issue to the states to decide," he said in a statement. 
 
 "The Democratic Party remains committed to equal protection under the law for all Americans. How we achieve that goal continues to be the subject of a contentious debate, but our Party continues to oppose constitutional amendments that seek to short circuit the debate on how to achieve equality for all Americans."
BobNelson2

I know it's fashionable -- and highly encouraged by Mr. soon-to-be-indicted Rove -- to complain that the Democrats don't stand for anything, but isn't it kind of stupid to do so in the middle of a thread about how one guy -- no doubt pandering, but still one politician -- misstated the Democratic position when the official position of the Democratic Party -- approved by way more than one person -- is our full equality?
 
 Sure, Dems are all over the board on the issue -- largly depending on WHERE they are, but the direction of the party is clear. In the large states of CA, NY, NJ and in smaller but important states like OR, MA, etc. the Democratic Party has passed or is trying to pass same-sex MARRIAGE or FULLY-EQUAL civil unions.
 
 Furthermore, EVERY SINGLE pro-gay law in this country has been passed by majority Democratic support. If the House and Senate were in Democratic hands, we would have FEDERAL anti-discrimination protection in a snap.
BobNelson2

And, yes, Dean is a twit.
 
 He's so desperate to "reach out" to those Christians who watch the 700 Club that he can't see that they will NEVER EVER vote Democratic. It's weird.
BobNelson2

Right on Matthew! We can become like France and have an insane unemployment rate!

 
 The French count ALL unemployed people. WE only count them for six months, then they drop off the edge of the earth and are no longer included in what we laughingly call the "unemployment rate". If you measured our employment situation the same way the French measure theirs, or measure theirs the way we measure ours, there wouldn't be nearly the difference you think there is.

 But to get to your bet, I hope to have EU citizenship in the next few years, but I'm going through my mother's homeland, Italy. I know they want me (well, my sister does). 
 
 With each passing year, having an exit strategy seems to make more and more sense.
